subject: RE: [junit] JUnit4 and legacy classes with static Test suite()
msgSnippet: Dear Mirko, Thank you for the defect report. You are correct that JUnitCore is not running 3.8.x test classes with a suite() method. I think this behavior is
messageBody:
Dear Mirko,

Thank you for the defect report. You are correct that JUnitCore is not
running 3.8.x test classes with a suite() method. I think this behavior is
incorrect. We will look at this during our next coding session.

The following test should pass (and doesn't):

import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;

import org.junit.runner.JUnitCore;
import org.junit.runner.Result;
import org.junit.runner.RunWith;
import org.junit.runners.AllTests;


public class JUnitCoreShouldRunSuite extends TestCase {
public static class Tests extends TestCase {
public void testNothing1() {
}
public void testNothing2() {
}
}

// @RunWith(AllTests.class) If you uncomment this line the test will
pass
public static class SuiteClass {
public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
TestSuite result= new TestSuite();
result.addTestSuite(Tests.class);
return result;
}
}

public void testJUnitCoreRunsSuites() {
Result result= JUnitCore.runClasses(SuiteClass.class);
assertEquals(2, result.getRunCount());
assertEquals(0, result.getFailureCount());
}
}

Also, I have updated the cookbook.

Thank you again.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Mirko N.
> Sent: Monday, May 29, 2006 4:17 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit4 and legacy classes with static Test suite()
>
> Hi,
>
> I'm doing some tests to see how easy it would be for us to upgrade to
> JUnit4. Ideally the new runner should be able to run all of our
> existing JUnit3.8 tests without modifications.
>
> The Cookbook suggests to use
> org.junit.runner.TextListener.run(TestClass1.class, ...) as
> TestRunner; but looks like that bit of documentation is out of date.
>
> Apparently JUnitCore is the class that does the job. In fact it works
> very well with regular TestCases. But it doesn't seem to recognize
> classes with a static Test suite() method. E.g.
>
> $ java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore some.junit38.tests.StaticSuiteTest
> JUnit version 4.1
> .E
> Time: 0.018
> There was 1 failure:
> 1) warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1)
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: No tests found in
> some.junit38.tests.StaticSuiteTest
>
> while with the old runner
>
> $ java junit.textui.TestRunner some.junit38.tests.StaticSuiteTest
> ..........
> Time: 0.004
> OK (10 tests)
>
> If I annotate the legacy StaticSuiteTest with @RunWith(AllTests.class)
> then the new runner is happy. But that means having to find out all
> classes using static suite() in our codebase, annotate and
> recompile them.
>
> Before delving into the new JUnit code, is this behaviour expected?
>
> Thanks
>
> Mirko
